comments.commentBody: The over/under on human extinction? I've heard at least one person not presumptively a crackpot, a distinguished scientist in fact, setting 100 years on the low end. I thought the Yellowstone blast was predicted closer to 150,000 years out, but even so humans will have left the stage well before that. How soon? I have no anxiety about it, and no real sense about how to predict it, although having lived through the worst years of the Cold War, as did many still with us, the inevitability of our species vanishing is much easier to accept than the sense that nuclear annihilation may occur at any moment.

I am someone who has not read any of these books but is always interested in the views of the younger generation and their perceptions. I have always looked at life as a series of problems or challenges to be solved. The excitement working thru them usually inspired family, co-workers, and strangers to challenge them selves. The world we are seeing and hearing today may be scary but the solutions are staring us in the face if we choose to look. There is nothing wrong with presenting the dark side as long as it motivates us not get there.

What is the apocalypse but an everlasting snow day? You capture something real there-- that the apocalypse basically eliminates all the rules. You can have a million variations on how it takes place to please different demographic audiences, but I think that's the core appeal.

But I also think this is a generation of kids that grew up seeing real horrors that their parents did not see as children-- the towers crashing on 9/11, bodies floating in murky water in New Orleans-- if those weren't apocalyptic visions, I don't know what would be. And yet for most of us, life continued with its cozy abundance of shelter and food and entertainment. The focus stayed on consumption and commerce. So even when someone truly horrifying occured, life went on pretty much as it had before.

So I think most kids do NOT feel fear or uncertainty that draws them to these books. I think they want to vicariously experience fears they know they're not likely to encounter. Because most teenagers' lives are provincial, comfortable and uneventful in the grand scheme of things and not likely to change.

From the time kids enter kindergarten they are made to feel that the world is headed in the wrong direction, that faith is something to laugh at, that doomsday is looming just around the corner if we don't recycle our plastics, that sex is what all relationships revolve around and they should be thinking about their sexual orientation when they are 8 years old.  If we let kids just be kids without making them feel guilty for just living in the world while increasing their worry and rumination, maybe they would not feel the weight of the world on their shoulders.  Is it any wonder they seek to escape reality with drugs, alcohol, and even suicide when all the joy has been taken from their formative minds and bodies? Why can't we just let kids be kids? "...a time for every purpose under heaven"?  There is nothing as powerful as a spiritual life and prayer in an individual's life, whether they are 8 or 88.

I guess American teenagers' emotional needs aren't being met, because why else would they so consistently be drawn to "poor me" themes in music and literature.  They really don't have to do anything more physically demanding than turning on the iWhatever.  I guess having your material needs satisfied frees you up to be unhappy about everything else.

Portraying a dystopian reality is one thing, creating poorly written dark characters who bite their way through anemic plot lines and then serving it up as literature is something else.  To echo Jay Scott, it's creepy that poor writers are allowed to make money off of the hormonal drives of adolescents.  Good books are being written: finding them at the chain bookstores is hard.

My dear grandson is 16. While he is obsessed with mathematics, for which he has a freakishly extraordinary talent, and will almost surely follow in certain family footsteps to become a research mathematician, he is unusual in that he is also preoccupied with philosophy and literature.

I say with pride that he scorns what he recently characterized as "the intellectual ghetto" (!) of so-called "children's" and "teen" literature. He obviously detests these unsubtle, hectoring ideological pamphlets, despite his mother's unfortunate employment at a city library which seems to have an infinite supply of these whiny, lecturing, and invariably hard-left politicized texts.

On Thanksgiving, I made him an early gift of two superb books: Matt Ridley's "The Rational Optimist," and Boswell's great and terrible "Life of Samuel Johnson" in the beautiful compact Everyman's edition. His reaction to these -- which he has devoured in a mere month -- confirmed my hopes in the best and most brilliant of this young generation, to wit:

It appears he found a passage in Boswell that has thrilled him at the deepest, philosophical level; the awesome passage where Johnson so memorably enjoins Boswell to "clear your mind of cant." Since I have quoted this very passage rather boorishly on too many occasions over the long dinnered years, I was particularly delighted to see it strike afresh the mind of one so young and brilliant.

He has already gotten into trouble in "soft classes" at his (supposedly superb, in truth mediocre) school for accusing the teachers of "spouting cant." Since even in this context of the gifted (and pampered) his brilliance is commanding, the teachers are left with little to do except gape as the boy trots out study after fact after study after fact that make a mockery of their cherished "environmentalist" canards and shibboleths.

He would never tolerate the *cant* that is spoon-fed to "children" and "teens" by the sinister texts we’re discussing here. He sees this nihilism for what it is and rejects it utterly. I regret I will not see his maturity, but I am confident it will be known to many as an exemplary life of truth-seeking. And this in the face of the despicable politicized hysteria that passed for "truth-telling" in the wretched schools and "teen literature" of his youth.

This is varied and interesting set of comments which seems to reflect well on the opportunity for expression that teen literature invites.

I suggest that we really need to hear more from the younger people themselves. And this time lets listen.

"I think the absolute black and white choices in dark young adult novels are incredibly satisfying for readers," I agree that the ultimatums produced by Armageddon type stories, are appealing because they often lead to scenarios where the meaning of life is one dimensional or even worse digital.  What if the oil runs out, and it isn't the end of the world.

I disagree that kids in bad situations don't want to read about bad situations, because my students who deal with issues of violence, addiction, rape and poverty on a regular basis relish these "Child Called It" and "Precious" novels that mirror some of the horror they and their peers see in real life. They also love the dystopian, "world is ending", f my life-type novels.

In response to #5, please remember that teenagers are children. It's not their responsibility yet to fight society. It's ours as the adults who have some control over what is happening. We blame corporate executives and buy only stocks that provide quick profits. We blame lawyers and hire them to do their damnedest on our behalf. We blame politicians and sit out elections. Democracy works...for people who work at it.

Why has no one remarked yet on the overabundance of mutant/alien/vampire/angel/werewolf/supernatural fixation going on in YA books? So many tales of too good to be true love with perfect specimens of beauty. Heroines who aresupposedly introverted yet independent models who long to just have a normal life. I could go on but I think I'm craving a good book ;)

I expected to be fried to a crisp as a kid. Fifty years later I still expect it. I grew up reading science fiction and as a result all this worry about contemporary dark YA fiction pales against duck under your desk and kiss your butt goodbye. A Canticle for Liebowitz, anyone? I read it before my balls dropped.

Excellent point about the fact that "every single awful thing" gets reported these days -- news comes at people (even kids) via TV, radio, Internet, cellphone text. It's comical and ridiculous, when you think about it. Even children who might not show an interest in the worst stories of the day cannot escape it. In a way, it's good to be informed. On the other hand, knowing what kids know today about real-life newsworthy and not-so-newsworthy events means that literature needs to be that much more interesting, now. Fiction is supposed to be stranger than reality -- but if Youtube clips of the truly weird are being shared on Facebook, authors have to create alternate realities that stand alone as fantastic, and not just what happens every day.

Dystopian literature is prechow teenagers are escaping from books like "The O'Reilly Factor for Kids" and "The Book of Virtues": they're trying to avoid having ideology spoon-fed at them in a world where such thoughts are no longer applicable, or even held by anyone they know.

I completely agree with you on how fictional dystopias inspire the readers to avert the oncoming future. To add on, I think that fictional dystopias also allow the readers to form their own opinions and learn about the underlying real- world issues that the stories discuss. Also, us young adults generally don't read fictional dystopias because we want to read about our supposedly inevitable, horrible future. We read them because we want some variety in plot and the norm. The usual everyday life and rules become quite boring; personally, I feel that it is much more interesting to read about what I would perceive as twists and turns in a very corrupt society

"There is in fact plenty of green energy: wind alone could meet America's power needs four times over. But we've chosen to protect the interests of oil and coal companies."

Actually, what we have is Americans of all stripes insisting that wind turbines belong in someone else's back yard, or on a horizon visible from someone else's beach house. Combine that with the idiots screaming "socialism!" at any program designed for the public good, and you have the conservative ideal: no change. Protecting that which already is benefits all entrenched industries.

Tales of a dystopian future, as Bradbury observed, are powerful tools: they inspire the reader, if the reader is still young (or at least still thoughtful), to engage in acts, great or small, that may avert the future described. Few teens, given the political power to do so, would oppose a wind farm in their own back yards, and dystopian fiction improves the chances that this sensibility will stay with them as they inevitably acquire property, power, and a political voice.

I think Sci-Fi - not fantasy, not alternative worlds or timelines, not horror (though Stephen King's horror is many times just our world with a slight slant to it and not necessarily supernatural) - are the only authors asking us to examine what might happen if we keep on certain paths.  Truly good sci-fi authors have always done that.  Not that we've always paid attention - or we wouldn't be living the early stages of 1984 and Brave New World.  There are some really good sci-fi authors - YA and adult - out there right now who are asking some hard questions of us.  Read before you make up your minds.

Use of the term "backing into the playoffs" only highlights the math inadequacy of the speaker/writer, as well as the math cluelessness of America in general.

The Jets (or any team for that matter) make the playoffs based on an entire season of work, not the results of one week. Would it be more of an accomplishment if Jacksonville had won yesterday, and the Jets clinched by winning next week? (answer for the math-challenged super-majority: No.) The Jets have made the playoffs because they have won 10 games, order not important, a feat only seven other teams can boast of.

If people are concerned about how teams make the playoffs, they should be more concerned that the NFC West will crown a "champion" who will not have won a majority of its games (and, could have a losing record). That is a problem.

P.S. - By the way, even by this flawed thinking, the Jets did not "back into the playoffs" last year. They needed to beat Cincinnati in the last game of the season, and they did to earn their playoff place (and win two more road playoff games). Please get your made up facts straight.

There are very three simple ways of improving the US unemployment problem and the data will take care of themselves:

1) Level the playing field for companies that employ Americans instead of sending jobs overseas.

2) Protect manufacturing. It is the way for middle-class families to make it but has largely gone away due to low-paying service jobs as (poor) substitutes.

3) Promote American goods! And that means actually making good products that we can be proud of. A place to start is to look at German-made cars and what kind of pride they put into their work.

Thomas Huynh
Sonshi.com

..."“They’re losing the idea that if you are determined and work hard, you can get ahead,” said Dr. Van Horn. “They’re losing that sense of optimism. They don’t think that they or their children are going to fare particularly well.”

Yes, Mr. Herbert, joblessness is a terrible, economic nightmare. However losing optimism is not necessarily a bad thing. In fact, for many (if not most) Americans, it may be a good thing. We have been for too long a "feel good" culture, using denial as our main defense. (No, nothing terrible will happen to us again. We will find a way to ensure our safety. This after the 9/11 attacks.) Little did we realize that the terrorism we were about to experience was not about airplanes hitting Trade Towers and the Pentagon, but about precipitously losing jobs and, as time went on, hope of finding decent employment. At this point, I think many Americans are completely out of denial and, perhaps, able to see the truth of our corporate dominated culture. More people realize our government stands for and by the richest and greediest among us. Period.

This is a sad truth. However, it is necessary for millions of us to realize in order to stand together in effective protest--as we did during the Vietnam War. Nothing will happen until we do!
